Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Galactic Archeology: Elemental Abundances in the Milky Way Halo

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemical Composition of Stars in the Milky Way Halo

 

I am interested in how our Galaxy – the Milky Way – formed. Our galaxy is a typical spiral galaxy, and understanding how it formed can tell us a lot about the formation of galaxies in general. While we often imagine the Milky Way as a flat disk or spiral, one of its other components is a very large but dim halo. The halo is an agglomeration of stars moving in random directions around the Galaxy’s center (no net rotation). We currently believe that many of these stars did not form in our own Galaxy, i.e. they formed in satellite galaxies that were subsequently accreted and ripped apart by the Milky Way. This is a key aspect of galaxy formation that astronomers are trying to address. In order to test this hypothesis, astronomers compare the chemical patterns found in stars in recently discovered satellite galaxies to those in stars belonging to the Milky Way halo. In order to do a proper comparison between these two populations, it is best to compare stars with similar physical properties (brightness and size). Because of their large distances, only the brightest red giant stars (see link below) are accessible in the satellite galaxies. However, stars with lower brightness and higher temperature dominate the comparison samples of halo stars.

 

I used my East Asia and Pacific Summer Fellowship to conduct research at the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan (NAOJ), located in the outskirts of Tokyo. This institute manages the 8.2-meter Subaru telescope in Hawaii – one of the largest telescopes in the world used for this kind of stellar chemical analysis, as well as being home to Prof. Wako Aoki, a leading astronomer in the study of the chemical properties of stars in the halo.  During my summer at NAOJ, I learned how to calculate the chemical abundances of such stars using very high-resolution stellar spectra, and applied this knowledge to extract such information from the spectra of 40 stars belonging to the halo. The chemical elements analyzed include iron, calcium, magnesium, titanium, sodium, chromium, and zinc. These elements, among others, have also been studied in stars belonging to satellite galaxies.

 

I plan to continue this research project by comparing the chemical patterns of the stars in my sample to the patterns found in thee satellite galaxies, now that the data analysis is complete.  Although this is not the first study to do so, it is one of the first to focus primarily on stars with similar physical properties.  Through this element-by-element comparison, I hope to quantify the level of similarity between the halo and the satellite galaxies. This research will contribute to our understanding of how part of our Milky Way was formed. This research is closely tied to my thesis research, which focuses on the evolution of the faintest satellite galaxies orbiting the Milky Way via the study of their component stars.
